dardiff_alg
===========

Important ideas:
* split by line by ORF; add new long string of characters as new line
* put character-level inserts/removals as new lines for easier tracking

###GENBANK FILE:
<metadata, annotations> <!-- we'll deal with this later -->



----------------------------------

###VCSFMT FILE:
<metadata, annotations>

DNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNA <!-- SPLIT BY ORF AND OTHER HEURISTICS -->
DNADNADNADNADNADNA
DNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNA
DNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNA
DNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNA
[[COMMIT HASH]][[ADDED ORF MARKER]]DNADNADNADNADNADNA <!-- ADDED SEQUENCE TO NEXT LINE WHICH CHANGES ORF LINEBREAK -->
DNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNA
DNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNA
[[COMMIT HASH]]DNADNADNADNADNADNA <!-- INSERTED LINE; HASH REQUIRED FOR RECONSTITUTION OF HISTORY FROM INITIAL COMMIT --> 
DNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNA
DNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNA
DNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNADNA

=========================== <!-- CHARACTER SUBSTITUTIONS --> <!-- equal signs not actually shown -->
[[COMMIT HASH]][[char;line number;column;insert/delete]][[c;l;p;i/d]][[clpid]][[]][[]][[]][[]]...
=========================== <!-- EOF -->
* line number/column/(insert/delete) represented in binary for log n space efficiency
* i.e. line number is represented in binary, using the 8 bits of the byte it's encoded in
* because of this (because we're not just using ascii), there needs to be a delimiting byte
* let's make that byte 0xFF (all 1s)
* i *would* say that using absolute line number is bad, but because the file git keeps track of just keeps appending incremental changes to build up the most recent file from the initial commit, they can be applied in order just fine
* that, or maybe i'm wrong and we have to have some hash of the line

* git must apply the character substitutions before going to next commit
* this may have to take the form of an extra git commit?
* that way that character substitutions line only contains the substitutions with respect to the previous darwin commit
* don't ever apply the character substitutions; just keep them in history at bottom, continually appending as commits build up; when some limit is reached, make highly compressed version of exact file, signed with hash of commit, then use that for more recent history instead of applying every charsub line from beginning
	* to clarify that; after some limit is reached, compress the current VCSFMT file (from which the entire history can be reconstructed) and take the current genbank file as the initial commit (not really, just as an analogy), and do diffs from that
	* this way the VCSFMT avoids carrying buttloads of info from way back when without massive compression
* OH YEAH AND COMPRESS EVERYTHING TO SINGLE-LETTER AMINO ACIDS

-------------------------------

###NOTES ON VCSFMT

#### NEED WAY TO COMPRESS INITIAL POSSIBLY MASSIVE COMMIT FOR TRANSMITTING OVER BANDWIDTH (THIS IS TRIVIAL)

**STILL NEED METHOD OF DEALING WITH LONG SEQUENCE BEING ADDED THAT /DOESN'T/ CHANGE ORF**

#### HOW ORFS CAN CHANGE AS LETTERS/LINES ARE ADDED/REMOVED

* when new sequence added such that orf changes (say, AUGXXX... appended to front of previous orf):
	* [[COMMIT HASH]][[ORFADDEDCODE]]AUGXXX...
	* continue sequence until end of line, then go onto next line (the one that previously existed), which is recognized by comparing it against the previous VCSFMT file
	* ORFADDEDCODE will be a 8-bit sequence, perhaps the same as the delimiting byte 0xFF introduced earlier
